active_learning.discussion_prompt: How would you apply this concept in your work environment?
active_learning.peer_teaching: In pairs, one student demonstrates scanning a target (e.g., using nmap --script ssl-enum-ciphers -p 443 example.com or testssl.sh example.com) to identify weak ciphers; the partner explains the findings, vulnerabilities (e.g., RC4 stream cipher biases), and mitigations. Switch roles and discuss results as a group.
active_learning.problem_solving: Using a vulnerable web server setup (e.g., Docker container with outdated TLS config supporting RC4/3DES), students: 1) Scan for weak ciphers with multiple tools; 2) Classify findings (weak vs. strong); 3) Recommend mitigations (e.g., update to TLS 1.3 with AES-GCM); 4) Role-play presenting a pen test report to 'stakeholders'.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

Use these sources for accuracy: OWASP Testing Guide v4 (WSTG-CRYP-03), NIST SP 800-52 Rev2, RFC 8446 (TLS 1.3), RFC 7465 (RC4 Deprecation), PCI-DSS v4.0 (Req 4.1), Mozilla SSL Config Generator. Incorporate university pedagogy: Bloom's Taxonomy objectives [insert learning_objectives array]; active learning [insert active_learning object]; 4-layer scaffolding [insert scaffolding object]. Generate 75 high-quality flashcards following this schema [insert flashcard_schema object]. Balance: 20% Layer1/REMEMBER-UNDERSTAND, 30% Layer2-3/APPLY-ANALYZE, 30% Layer3/EVALUATE, 20% Layer4/CREATE. Types: 30% definitions, 30% MCQs (w/ distractors), 20% tool commands, 10% comparisons, 10% scenarios. Examples: Weak suites: TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5, TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA. Strong: TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384. Tools: nmap --script ssl-enum-ciphers -p 443 host; testssl.sh host; openssl s_client -connect host:443. Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcard objects. Ensure engaging, precise, and educational.
